Efficient Nickel-Iron bimetallic nanoparticles catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of biomass-derived sugars to sugar alcohols Naseeb Ullah Investigation Writing – original draft François Jérôme Writing – review & editing Karine De Oliveira Vigier Supervision Conceptualization Writing – review & editing ⁎ C2MP, UMR CNRS 7285-Université de Poitiers, ENSIP, B1, 1 rue Marcel Doré, TSA 41105, Poitiers Cedex 9 86073, France C2MP UMR CNRS 7285-Université de Poitiers ENSIP B1, 1 rue Marcel Doré, TSA 41105, Poitiers Cedex 9 86073 France C2MP, UMR CNRS 7285-Université de Poitiers, ENSIP, B1, 1 rue Marcel Doré, TSA 41105, Poitiers Cedex 9 86073, France ⁎ Corresponding author. Herein, we demonstrate that a bimetallic nickel-iron based nanoparticles synthesized by simple one-pot hydrothermal method was active and selective in the hydrogenation of sugars to sugar alcohols. To investigate the catalytic performance of NixFey bimetallic nanoparticles, hydrogenation reactions were performed in water starting from biomass derived monosaccharides (xylose, mannose, rhamnose, arabinose, galactose). The molar Ni:Fe ratio was studied and it appears that a bulk composition of Ni:Fe of around 3:1 is active in such reactions. Hence, the Ni3Fe1 BMNPs gives high yield (99%) of corresponding sugar alcohols (with selectivity up to 99%) under mild conditions. The efficient catalytic activity of Ni3Fe1 BMNPs is ascribed to the synergistic actions of Ni and Fe bimetallic composition. The catalyst was recyclable up to 9 consecutive cycles. Furthermore, the catalytic potential of Ni3Fe1 bimetallic nanoparticles was demonstrated starting from different monosaccharides to produce sugar alcohols. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Heterogeneous catalysis Bimetallic metal nanoparticles Water Hydrogenation reaction Sugar alcohols Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The depletion of fossil carbon resources and increasing concerns on global warming are the major factors that elevated the need to change radically the way we produce, consume and use resources [1]. In recent years, renewable resources, particularly lignocellulosic biomass, have gained immense attention for sustainable production of fuels and platform chemicals [2,3]. In lignocellulosic biomass, a particularly interesting group of molecules derived from carbohydrates fraction are sugar alcohols (i.e. xylitol, galactitol and sorbitol) [4–5]. Pentose-derived sugar alcohols include arabitol, xylitol, and ribitol, whereas mannitol and sorbitol are the most relevant representatives of hexose-derived sugar alcohols [6]. Sugars alcohols find various application in foods products as thickeners and sweeteners. For instance, xylitol is a sweetener, which has been commercialized due to its striking properties as high solubility in water, stability upon storage and does not caramelize at elevated temperatures [7]. Furthermore, the sweetening capacity of xylitol exceeds that of sucrose by 20–25% with no insulin obligation [8]. Sugar alcohols are also added to toothpaste and chewing gum formulations for their anticaries effect, as oral bacteria cannot ferment them. In general practice, sugar alcohols are produced by the catalytic hydrogenation of monosaccharides. As an example, xylitol is produced by catalytic hydrogenation of xylose in triphasic batch reactors, where the reagent and catalysts are dispersed in an aqueous medium. Raney Ni catalyst is mainly adopted in such reaction owing to its comparable activity and lower price index as compared to noble metals based catalysts [9]. However, the leaching of nickel during hydrogenation and the low activity make this catalyst less profitable, because a refilling of the catalyst and a purification of product to remove residual Ni are required, which eventually render this process economically less attractive [10]. Among the developed heterogeneous catalysts, precious metals (i.e., Pt, Pd, Ru, Rh) are found catalytically more active and stable against leaching than Raney Ni catalyst. Particularly, ruthenium (Ru) and palladium (Pd) exhibits the highest activity and selectivity potential in hydrogenation reactions for the organic transformations [11–15]. However, the use of an expensive metal-catalyst, energy consuming conditions, and downstream processes limits the economic feasibility of reaction at industrial scale. Therefore, the catalyst development trends are shifting towards costly earth abundant transition metals (i.e., Ni, Cu, Co and Fe) [16,17]. Individually, metallic Ni is identified to efficiently catalyze hydrogenation reactions, but one of its major drawbacks lies in its lack of selectivity, due to side-reactions of hydrogenolysis and over-hydrogenation [18]. Raney nickel was promoted by molybdenum, chromium, and iron [19–22]. Among these metals, Fe as a promoter can maximally enhance the activity of Ni catalysts [23]. Moreover, the magnetic properties of Fe make it easy to separate and thus to recycle the catalyst. Therefore, the composition of the second metal (i.e., Ni-Fe, Ni-Co and Ni/Cu) can be advantageous due to its low-price value and largest availability and with the probability to promote the catalytic activity to great extent [23]. Hence, it was demonstrated that a NiFe/C catalyst contains less oxidized Fe and Ni in the alloy form than monometallic Fe/C and Ni/C [24]. Thus, metallic Fe and Ni sites are present at the catalyst surface which contribute to the splitting of hydrogen required in hydrogenation reaction. Moreover, the stability is enhanced due to preservation of the overall morphology of the catalyst by the addition of the promotor. In this work, the hydrogenation of sugars (xylose, mannose rhamnose, arabinose) to sugar alcohols was studied in the presence of nickel-iron bimetallic nanoparticles (BMNPs) prepared by a one-pot hydrothermal reaction and in water In Scheme 1 is presented the hydrogenation of xylose reaction as an example. The NixFey BMNPs catalyst was chosen due to the fact that BMNPs displayed higher catalytic efficiencies in contrast to their monometallic counterparts, due to the strong synergy between the metals [22]. Particularly, Ni-based bimetallic catalyst exhibit specific properties, via a synergistic or bi-functional effect, which differ from those of the parent metals and offer the opportunity to design catalysts with composition of bimetallic particles affect their catalytic properties, these parameters should be precisely characterized and optimized in order to correlate the catalyst formulation and its performances in reaction [25]. Moreover, the magnetic properties of these BMNPs will help to recover the catalyst at the end of the reaction that is a real added value of using such materials. The catalytic potential of NxFey BMNPs was studied in the hydrogenation of sugar (xylose) into corresponding polyols (xylitol) in aqueous phase reaction systems. The effect of various reaction parameters on the overall performance of the catalyst were discussed in detail as well as the stability of the catalyst in the two reaction media. The scope of the reaction was also studied. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Chemicals Ferrous sulfate (FeSO4.7H2O), nickel(II) chloride (NiCl2), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), hydrazine hydrate (H2NNH2.H2O) and ethylene glycol (HOCH2CH2OH) was obtained from Merck. The sugar substrates such as D-xylose, D-mannose, L-arabinose, D-galactose and L-mannose were acquired the commercially available and were used as received. 2.2 Synthesis of Ni3Fe1 bimetallic nanoparticles (BMNPs) The Ni3Fe1 bimetallic nanoparticles (BMNPs) were synthesized by using hydrothermal method. Typically, FeSO4.7H2O and NiCl2 in certain molar ratio of Ni:Fe (3:1) was dissolved into 200 mL deionized water and 4 mL of ethylene glycol solution. Afterwards, NaOH (16 mL, 1 M) solution was added to the mixture dropwise and adjusting the pH value around 9 and hydrazine hydrate (2 mL) was used as reducing agent. The mixture solution was well stirred under N2 atmosphere and then transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and placed in a heating furnace adjusted at 125°C for 16 h. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature (RT) naturally and the as-prepared Ni3Fe1 BMNPs (black solid phase) were separated by using a magnetic bar. Finally, the obtained product was washed and re-dispersed in DI water and methanol several times and vacuum dried. The monometallic nanoparticles of Ni and Fe are prepared similarly but without addition of the binary source of metal. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed in a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The operating voltage and current were 40kV and 40mA, respectively. The step length was 0.02° with scanning rate of 2°/min from 10 to 95°. A PerkinElmer SCIEX ICP Mass Spectrometer Elan 6100 DRC Plus and a Optima 5300DV ICP Optical Emission Spectrometer were used to measure the Ni-Fe contents in the catalyst and in the reaction medium. The nanoparticles were digested in 5 % nitric acid in a 1:20 dilution from a 1 g/L nanoparticle suspension. Experiments were performed at the Institut de Chimie des Milieux et Matériaux de Poitiers (IC2MP) at the Poitiers University using Agilent 5110 ICP-OES instrument. The detection limits were 0.014 ppm for Fe and 0.018 ppm for Ni. Three aliquots were measured from each sample and the resulting concentrations were averaged. Reported values have been adjusted for the dilution with nitric acid. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was made on a Kratos Ultra system employing an Al Kα radiation source. The binding energies for each spectrum were calibrated with a C1s spectrum of 284.6 eV. Survey spectrum was calibrated for the sample over a binding energy range of 0-1100 eV were recorded at pass energy of 160 eV and resolution of 1 eV per step. High-resolution spectra of Ni 2p and Fe were recorded at pass energy of 40 eV and resolution of 0.1 eV per step, for quantitative measurement of binding energy. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiments at 77 K were performed on a TriStar 3000 instrument to determine specific surface area (by multipoint Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method). 2.4 Aqueous-phase catalytic hydrogenation of sugar In a typical aqueous-phase hydrogenation reaction, 0.1 g of as-prepared catalyst (Ni3Fe1 BMNPs) was ultrasonically dispersed in 5 mL H2O containing 1 g substrate (10 wt.% xylose). Afterwards, the prepared solution was shifted to a Teflon-lined tube jacketed mechanically driven stainless steel autoclave reactor (25 mL, Parr 5500, USA), equipped with stirring arrangement. The reactor was sealed and flushed three times with N2 to expel air/oxygen from the system and then purged with H2 gas up to corresponding desired pressure (bar) at ambient temperature. The reaction temperature (°C) and time (h) were optimized at certain values with constant magnetic stirring. After the reaction completion, the reactor was cooled down to RT naturally and the unreacted H2 was vented off. The catalyst was eliminated by using a permanent magnet bar and a sample from the liquid-phase was collected by using a syringe filter before transferring to HPLC examination. Overall, the experiments in this study are repeated for three times and the average value data is presented with experimental error less than 2%. 2.5 Quantitative analysis of catalytic liquid product Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyzed liquid-phase product was quantitatively analyzed by HPLC-RID (LC-20AD Shimadzu-Japan) equipped with auto sampler assembly SIL-10A and a controller CBM 20A. The products were separated on Varian 100-5 amino S 250 × 4.6 mm (NH2) column using acetonitrile/water (80/20, vol. ratio) as eluent, the flow rate was kept 0.8 mL.min−1 at 40°C. The refractive index detector (model no. RID-6A) was used for the detection and calibration of compounds. The calibration curve of each compound was done by acquiring the commercially available standards. The substrate conversion (%) and yield (%) of sugar alcohol and was calculated based on the following given equations; (i) Conversion ( % ) = [ substrate ( mol ) ] i − [ substrate ( mol ) ] f [ substrate ( mol ) ] i x 100 (ii) Sugar alcohol Yield ( % ) = sugar alcohol in product ( mol ) [ substrate ( mol ) ] i x 100 (iii) Selectivity ( % ) = [ sugar alcohol in product ( mol ) ] All product formed ( mol ) x 100 Whereas, [substrate (mol)]i = initial moles of sugar substrate, [substrate (mol)]f = final moles of sugar substrate. 2.6 Catalyst recyclability test In order to determine the durability of the catalyst after each successive run of reaction, the catalyst was magnetically recovered and washed thoroughly by distilled water and methanol (3 × 10 mL) in an ultrasonic bath sonication at room temperature (25°C). Then, the used catalyst was reused with fresh charge of sugar for subsequent recycle runs under same reaction conditions. Notably, the recovered catalyst was processed consecutively for the next run without involving reactivation steps. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and effect of the molar Ni:Fe ratio The NixFey bimetallic nanoparticles catalysts were prepared using a hydrothermal wet-chemistry approach with different molar Ni:Fe ratio. ICP-OES analysis were performed to confirm the Ni:Fe ratio obtained (Table S2). The given Scheme 1 explains the experimental protocol involved in the preparation (see Experimental section for detail). All these catalysts have a specific surface area lower than 5 m2/g (Table S1, Fig. S1). Their catalytic properties were evaluated in the hydrogenation of xylose and are reported on Table 1 . Except for the molar ratio Ni:Fe 1:3, the xylose conversion was higher than 98% and the xylitol yield was above 93% for all the catalysts (Table 1). This is due to a higher amount of Fe and a lower amount of Ni for this catalyst compared to the others. Bimetallic particles were also compared to mono-metallic BMNPs (Ni and Fe, Table 1 entries 1-2) synthesized using the same hydrothermal synthesis protocol. BMNPs catalysts are more efficient than monometallic nanoparticles owing to the combinations of two metals as reported in the literature [23,26]. Hence, it can be due to the fact that Fe and Ni in the alloy form are in metallic form which is not the case using monometallic catalysts as it was shown previously [22,23]. The selective hydrogenation reaction of sugar monosaccharide is, thus, ascribed to the synergistic actions of Ni and Fe bimetallic composition. These results highlight the potential of using bimetallic catalysts for the production of sugar alcohols from sugars. The stability of the catalyst is very important in this reaction. Based on the magnetic properties of these BMNPs, the catalysts were recovered and reused without further treatment (Fig. 1 ). It was shown that three catalysts were recyclable up to 3 cycles without any significant loss in xylose conversion and xylitol yield. The recyclable catalysts were those with a molar Ni:Fe ratio of 2:1, 1:2 and 3:1. However, the yield of xylitol was slightly lower (93%) in the presence of Ni2:Fe1 BMNPs than in the presence of Ni1:Fe2 BMNPs and Ni3:Fe1 BMNPs. It appears that the optimum catalysts (high selectivity and stability) are those with a molar Ni:Fe ratio of 1:2 and 3:1. In order to understand why these two BMNPs are efficient and stable in the hydrogenation of xylose, with one catalyst enriched in Fe and the other one enriched in Ni, these two BMNPs were characterized by TEM analysis (Figs. 2 and 3 ). For these BMNPs, the majority of the nanoparticles are roughly spherical having coarse outer structure with heterogeneous particles size distribution. To further determine the distribution of Ni and Fe in Ni1Fe2 BMNPs and Ni3Fe1 BMNPs, EDS analysis were made on individual nanoparticles, as encircled on Figs. 2a and 3d. The nanoparticles labelled 2 and 3 contained 73% of Ni and 27% of Fe whereas the nanoparticles labelled 1 are composes of 5% of Ni and 95% of Ni (Fig. S2, Table S5). It means that in this catalyst, they are some particles that contain mainly Fe. For the Ni3Fe1 catalyst, (Fig. S3 and Table S5), the majority population of NPs showed high Ni elemental content but a few large particles enriched with Fe content were also observed. Indeed, most of the nanoparticles are with a 80% of Ni and 20% of Fe. However some of the particles are with a 15% of Ni and 85% of Fe. From all these results, we can note that both catalysts possess Ni-Fe species that are enriched in Ni with around 75%. XRD analysis of NixFey BMNPs were analyzed by XRD analysis. The obtained XRD patterns exhibit sharp and symmetrical reflection peaks that mainly correspond to Ni3Fe1 and Ni0.4 Fe2.6O4 as shown in Figs. 4 and 5 . The peaks appearing at 2θ of 44.2°, 51.5° and 75.8° correspond to the lattice plane of (111), (200) and (220) are the characteristic peak pattern of crystallized Ni3Fe1 (JCPDF file# 38-0419). Peaks appearing at 21.3°, 35.2°, 41.5°, 50.6°, 67.4° and 74.4° could be assigned to (111), (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) planes, respectively. These peaks coincide with the crystalline pattern of Fe2.6Ni0.4O4 (JCPDF file# 87-2337) magnetite. These two phases are present in all the catalysts with different proportion that can explain their activity. Hence the intensity of the peaks corresponding to the phase Ni3Fe1 is lower for the Ni1Fe3 catalyst than for the others, explaining why the activity of this catalyst was lower than the others. It seems that Ni3Fe1 phase is the active one in the hydrogenation of xylose to xylitol. Moreover, no isolated phases of individual Ni and Fe metals were observed suggesting that Ni and Fe are incorporated into their alloyed matrix, which also agree well with previous reports [27]. This result is in agreement with the TEM analysis. Based on these results, it appears that in order to reach a certain stability, BMNPs should be enriched in Ni and with a composition in bulk of Ni:Fe of 3:1 as reported in the literature. We thus decided to study deeply the Ni3Fe1 BMNPs in the hydrogenation of sugars in water. Further characterizations of this catalyst were performed to have a clear picture of the active species. The average diameter of Ni3Fe1 BMNPs was calculated by randomly selecting the size of numerous particles clearly seen in TEM images and the size distribution histogram is drawn and presented in inset in Fig. 3 (d). The size range of particles lies between 50 and 200 nm, with an average mean 150 nm calculated by using Nano measurer 1.2 version. Moreover, ICP-OES analysis was also performed to examine the composition of elemental content of Ni and Fe in the as-synthesized Ni3Fe1 BMNPs. The result shows that there is approximately 3 times (Fe 22 % and Ni 72 %) the concentration (mass) of Ni as Fe in the tested sample, which is overall consistent with the target theoretical ratio. Furthermore, the XPS analysis was conducted to elucidate the surface oxidation state of the Ni3Fe1 BMNPs. As represented in Fig. 6 (a), the obtained full scan survey confirms the presence representative Ni, Fe and O elements. The high resolution Ni 2p spectrum of the Ni/Fe bimetallic nanoparticles presented three peaks with the binding energies of 852.1, 855.4 and 873.2 eV via deconvolution, which could be assigned to the characteristic features of Ni0, Ni2+ (2p3/2) and Ni2+ (2p1/2), respectively, as depicted in Fig. 5(b). Whereas, the peak appearing at 861.1 eV assigned to the satellite peak (sat.- Ni(OH)2). On the other hand, the high resolution Fe 2p spectrum in Fig. 6 (c) can be deconvoluted into two main peaks appearing at 710.9 eV (2p3/2) and 723.4 eV (2p1/2), respectively, which were attributed to the iron oxides (Fe3O4). This oxide is present since the catalysts were stored with no particular precautions that leads to an external Fe oxide layer due to contact with air. The obtained content of individual element on the surface of the particles are measured to be Ni 56% and Fe 44% (Ni/Fe ca. ratio 1.3/1) (Table S6). From the comparison of XPS and ICP elemental analysis results it can be seen that Fe:Ni ratios are not similar showing that the internal and external compositions are different The obtained O 1s spectrum can be deconvoluted into three main peaks appearing at 529.3, 531.1 and 532.9 eV that was assigned to the O-Fe/O-Ni, OH and H2O, respectively, as depicted in Fig. 6 (d). 3.2 Optimization of aqueous-phase catalytic hydrogenation of sugar by Ni3Fe1 BMNPs The nature of the solvent was studied by performing hydrogenation of xylose in the presence of Ni3Fe1 bimetallic nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), it can be observed that if methanol and isopropanol were used as solvents the yield of xylitol was limited to only 39% and 53% respectively. The substrate conversion and product yield was substantially increased when H2O was the solvent (98% yield of xylitol was achieved at 99% conversion) due to the highest solubility of xylose in this solvent. Hence, the Ni3Fe1 BMNPs was found more performant in H2O. The kinetic of the reaction was then studied in water in the presence of Ni3Fe1 BMNPs (Fig. 8 ). Aliquots of the reaction media were drawn at different time interval and the substrate conversion and product yield were calculated by HPLC. Initially, a blank in the absence of any catalyst was conducted to demonstrate the importance of the catalyst and its effect on the hydrogenation reaction. No product such as xylitol was detected under catalyst-free conditions. Conversely, a steady and progressive increase in conversion of substrate and yield of target sugar alcohols was noticed when performing the reaction using Ni3Fe1 BMNPs as catalyst. Thus, the obtained result concludes that the presence of a catalyst is important to activate the hydrogenation reaction. Beside reaction medium, the temperature and H2 pressure are both important operational parameters and their effect on hydrogenation of xylose in the presence of Ni3Fe1 BMNPs was evaluated to find the most appropriate temperature to reach the highest yield into xylitol. Therefore, a series of reactions were performed under identified conditions but at variable temperatures, as depicted in Fig. 7 (b), It can be observed that the reaction temperature has a significant effect on the hydrogenation of xylose to xylitol. In the temperature range from 80 to 100°C, the yield of sugar alcohol notably increased after 3 h of reaction from 78% to 97% with the xylose conversion from 81% to 99%. However, the rise of temperature beyond the optimal temperature leads to a decrease of the yield of sugar alcohols and thus the selectivity. Therefore the temperatures exceeding 110°C were not studied due to the formation of by-products and sugar degradation. The effect of hydrogen pressure on xylose hydrogenation was examined by conducting reaction at constant catalyst to substrate mass ratio but with variable H2 pressure (i.e., 10, 20 and 30 bar). As shown in Fig. 7(c), when the reaction was performed at low H2 pressure (10 bar) without changing the other parameters (temperature and time), only 79% of xylose was converted to 77% of xylitol. An experiment with extended reaction time (4 h) at 10 bar H2 was conducted, giving 93% yield of xylitol. This shows that the decrease of the hydrogen pressure can be compensated by an increase of the reaction time. However, a lower H2 pressure of 5 bar with a reaction time of 4 h produced only 57% of xylitol with 59% of xylose conversion. Thus, it is inferred that increasing the hydrogen pressure increased the dissolved hydrogen concentration in aqueous mixture so that more hydrogen molecules could access Ni and Fe sites, which is accounted for the increased xylose conversion. Therefore, taking the catalytic efficiency into consideration, the optimal initial hydrogen pressure for this reaction was chosen to be 20 bar. In a view to demonstrate the long term stability of Ni3Fe1 BMNPs, its stability was studied upon 9 cycles. After each reaction, the spent catalyst was magnetically recovered from the liquid mixture and washed with distilled water and ethanol and then utilized for the next run. As shown in Fig. 7(d), the catalyst showed similar hydrogenation activity but a mild decline in the substrate conversion (9%) and the product yield (ca. 9%) was noticed after 9 consecutive cycles. This slight decrease in catalytic efficiency is attributed to the loss of catalyst during washing steps (around 2 to 3 mg were lost between each cycle). Moreover, to support this claim we characterized the recovered Ni3Fe1 BMNPs. By comparing the obtained XRD patterns, TEM images and EDS analysis with initial fresh Ni3Fe1 BMNPs catalyst the morphological stability was confirmed as well as the unchanged crystallinity after the hydrogenation reaction (Figs. S3, S4 and S7). The ICP-OES analysis of liquid phase hydrogenated product reveals that the Fe are more favorable leached (1.9 wt.% of the initial amount of Fe) than the Ni metal part (0.0084 wt.% of the initial amount of Ni) of the hydrothermally synthesized Ni3Fe1 BMNPs (Table S3). It can be due to the fact that some nanoparticles are enriched in Fe and these nanoparticles can be more prone to leach than the Ni-enriched nanoparticles. Moreover, XPS analysis of the recycled catalyst was performed, showing that Fe is leached and that some carbon are deposited on the catalyst surface, which is often reported in carbohydrates conversion (Table S6). Finally, the scope of the Ni3Fe1 BMNPs was extended beyond xylose by investigating different sugar-based substrates under optimized reaction conditions. Appreciably, the hydrothermally prepared Ni3Fe1 BMNPs was found active for the hydrogenation of a wide range of sugars by converting them into their corresponding polyols with yields above 90%, as shown in Table 2 . Although a lower yield was obtained starting from D-galactose, the selectivity into galactitol was around 98%. These results show the efficiency of such catalyst in the hydrogenation of sugars to sugar alcohols. 4 Conclusion Noble metal-free NixFey BMNPs have been synthesized hydrothermally under mild reaction conditions. It was demonstrated that the active species are with a bulk molar Ni:Fe ratio of 3:1. The morphology and elemental composition of this catalyst was characterized by XRD, TEM, EDS, XPS and ICP-OES analysis to obtain the detailed the chemical and structural information. The catalytic performance of Ni3Fe1 BMNPs was examined in aqueous-phase hydrogenation reactions using sugar monosaccharides as substrate. The obtained catalytic result reveals the outstanding potential for the active and selective hydrogenation of xylose to of corresponding sugar alcohols with high yield (up to 99%). The catalyst was recyclable up to 9th cycles thus confirming that the effectiveness of catalyst formulation for the promising production of sugar alcohols. The catalytic potential of Ni3Fe1 BMNPs was explored towards other monosaccharide substrate and proved efficient. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we demonstrate that a bimetallic nickel-iron based nanoparticles synthesized by simple one-pot hydrothermal method was active and selective in the hydrogenation of sugars to sugar alcohols. To investigate the catalytic performance of NixFey bimetallic nanoparticles, hydrogenation reactions were performed in water starting from biomass derived monosaccharides (xylose, mannose, rhamnose, arabinose, galactose). The molar Ni:Fe ratio was studied and it appears that a bulk composition of Ni:Fe of around 3:1 is active in such reactions. Hence, the Ni3Fe1 BMNPs gives high yield (99%) of corresponding sugar alcohols (with selectivity up to 99%) under mild conditions. The efficient catalytic activity of Ni3Fe1 BMNPs is ascribed to the synergistic actions of Ni and Fe bimetallic composition. The catalyst was recyclable up to 9 consecutive cycles. Furthermore, the catalytic potential of Ni3Fe1 bimetallic nanoparticles was demonstrated starting from different monosaccharides to produce sugar alcohols.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient Nickel-Iron bimetallic nanoparticles catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of biomass-derived sugars to sugar alcohols
